validated_hypotheses.hypothesis: Increasing budget allocation to the retargeting audience will increase overall ROAS.
validated_hypotheses.strengthened_reasoning: The retargeting audience's superior ROAS (14.40) compared to broad (8.06) and lookalike (9.66) audiences indicates a higher efficiency in converting existing interest. Allocating more budget capitalizes on this established efficiency, creating a causal effect where increased investment directly translates to higher overall ROAS due to the audience's propensity to convert. Causal relationship: More retargeting budget -> More conversions -> Higher overall ROAS.

validated_hypotheses.hypothesis: Replacing or refreshing creatives with high impressions and lower ROAS will improve overall campaign ROAS.
validated_hypotheses.strengthened_reasoning: Creatives with high impressions but lower ROAS suggest user fatigue or irrelevance. Replacing them introduces fresh content that is more likely to capture attention and drive conversions. This creates a causal link where new or refreshed creatives will reduce ad fatigue, leading to increased engagement and higher ROAS. Causal relationship: New creatives -> Higher engagement -> Higher ROAS.

validated_hypotheses.hypothesis: Increasing budget allocation to the US market will increase overall ROAS.
validated_hypotheses.strengthened_reasoning: The US market's higher ROAS (10.28) compared to the UK (9.08) and India (8.71) indicates a stronger return on ad spend. Allocating more budget to the US market leverages this higher-performing geography. Causal relationship: More US budget -> More conversions in US -> Higher overall ROAS.

validated_hypotheses.hypothesis: Pausing or replacing creatives with ROAS below 3 will improve overall campaign ROAS.
validated_hypotheses.strengthened_reasoning: Creatives with a ROAS below 3 are demonstrably inefficient, dragging down the overall campaign performance. Removing or replacing these underperforming creatives eliminates wasted ad spend and focuses resources on more profitable areas. Causal relationship: Fewer low ROAS creatives -> Higher average ROAS -> Higher overall ROAS.

validated_hypotheses.issue: Platform performance disparity between Facebook and Instagram.
validated_hypotheses.hypothesis: Reallocating budget from Instagram to Facebook will increase overall campaign ROAS.
validated_hypotheses.strengthened_reasoning: Given Facebook's higher ROAS (9.90) compared to Instagram (9.38), shifting budget from the latter to the former ensures that resources are allocated to the more efficient platform, driving overall campaign ROAS upward. Causal relationship: More Facebook budget, less Instagram budget -> More efficient ad spend -> Higher overall ROAS.

validated_hypotheses.hypothesis: Implementing more stable campaign settings (e.g., budget pacing, bid strategies) will reduce ROAS fluctuation and improve consistency.
validated_hypotheses.strengthened_reasoning: High ROAS fluctuation, with daily ROAS varying significantly, points to unstable campaign settings. Implementing more stable settings, such as controlled budget pacing and consistent bid strategies, is likely to reduce these fluctuations. Causal relationship: More stable campaign settings -> More predictable ad delivery -> Lower ROAS fluctuation and improved consistency.
